metadata.case_name: Trilok Singh and Pala Singh v. State

facts.text: Atma Singh purchased a plot of land measuring 58 kanals and 10 marlas in Basti Danish Mandan, Jullundur City in 1959 for Rs. 16,000 from Government at public auction.
Land was being cultivated by Hazara Singh and associates who were disinclined to give up possession.
Atma Singh appointed Ram Singh (PW 14) and Sham Singh (deceased) as attorneys to represent him in litigation concerning the land.
Attorneys obtained possession of the plot with police and revenue authorities help in June 1963.

Hazara Singh and 7-8 others including Trilok Singh s/o Surain Singh (accused no.1, appellant no.2) and Trilok Singh s/o Inder Singh (accused no.5) threatened attorneys with death unless they dissociated from litigation.
Sham Singh complained to City Inspector; Hazara Singh and Trilok Singh s/o Inder Singh proceeded against under s.107 CrPC.

Attorneys wanted to plough land but afraid; approached SP for police help against fee; land ploughed on June 26, 1963 in police presence; Hazara Singh, Trilok Singh s/o Inder Singh, Harnam Singh (father of Pala Singh) came armed with lathis but apprehended.
Police stayed on land for 5-6 days.
On August 9, 1963 crop on land found damaged; at instance of Ram Singh (PW14), police prosecuted Hazara Singh, Tara Singh, Channan, Trilok Singh s/o Inder Singh; all found guilty and convicted.
In November 1963, Hazara Singh, Harnam Singh, Bulkar Singh (brother of Pala Singh) and others prosecuted for ploughing land but acquitted.

On December 15, 1963, Hazara Singh and 17-18 others attacked Sham Singh and Ram Singh (PW14); police proceeded against Hazara Singh, Piar Kaur, Mahal Singh, Mangal Singh (brother of Trilok Singh s/o Surain Singh) under s.107 CrPC.

During pendency of proceedings, Sham Singh and Ram Singh attacked by six persons including Hazara Singh, two Trilok Singhs, Channan Singh, Harnam Singh, Nangal Singh; committed to sessions for s.307 IPC etc.; Sham and Ram to appear as PW; case adjourned to June 3, 1966 due to absence of Trilok Singh appellant.
On May 23, 1966 at 7:30 am, Laxman Singh (PW2) going from fuel depot to house; Sham Singh ahead, Narinder Singh (brother of deceased) 3-4 yards behind Laxman.

Near Babu Ram barber shop, Trilok Singh (appellant), Dhira (accused no.2) with kirpans, Pala Singh and Trilok Singh s/o Inder Singh with lathis appeared; Trilok s/o Inder shouted enemy come, murder him.
Dhira aimed kirpan at head of Sham Singh who caught it; pulled away; Pala Singh gave lathi blow below head, deceased fell face down; Trilok Singh (appellant) gave 3-4 kirpan blows on back of neck.
Eyewitnesses: Gokal Chand (PW3, Ayurvedic doctor nearby), Trilochan Singh (PW9, tractor driver passing by).

Additional Sessions Judge, Jullundur acquitted all five accused under ss.302,302/34,120B,302/309 IPC; held investigation by ASI Kashmiri Lal unfair, prosecution evidence untrustworthy, FIR delayed, special report delayed 8-9 hrs, inquest tampered, PWs 3 and 9 disbelieved, blood-stained sword recovery unreliable, site plan prepared later.

State appealed to Punjab & Haryana High Court (Crim App 385/1967); HC allowed in part, convicted Trilok Singh under s.302 IPC and Pala Singh under s.302/34 IPC, both life imprisonment; judgment May 15/16, 1969.

ASI Kashmiri Lal at 7:40 am at bus stand Basti Gujan; Laxman Singh gave statement Ex.PD (FIR basis) forwarded at 8:30 am; reached spot 8:40 am; prepared inquest Ex.PC, statements of Narinder and Gokal; sent body at 9:45 am.
SI Pritam Lal (PW13) received ruqa, recorded FIR Ex.PD/1 at 9:05 am, reached spot 10 am, took over investigation.
Occurrence report u/s 157 CrPC reached magistrate at 6 pm.
Site plan Ex.PH/1 prepared when body still there, before 9:45 am; later included s.120B.
Inquest statements of Narinder and Gokal originally mentioned two injuries by Trilok Singh sword; later '4' or 'four' added.
Medical showed five injuries.
Blood-stained sword recovered at instance of Trilok Singh appellant.
Distance between occurrence place and PS: 2.4 miles.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court was justified in re-appraising evidence and reversing the trial court's acquittal, given arguments of delayed FIR, tampered inquest report, delayed special report u/s 157 CrPC, and unreliable prosecution witnesses.
Scope of appellate court's power in appeal against acquittal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Trial court reasonably concluded prosecution witnesses unreliable after considering entire evidence; High Court not justified in re-appraising and disagreeing to convict appellants.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sanwat Singh v. State of Rajasthan; Ramabhupala Reddy v. State of AP; Bansidhar Mohanty v. State of Orissa

petitioner_arguments.text: FIR recorded after great delay and consultation; special report delayed 8-9 hours; inquest report tampered (added '4' to injuries, inserted s.120B in site plan); investigation unfair by ASI Kashmiri Lal.
Eye-witnesses have minor discrepancies; PW3 Gokal Chand and PW9 Trilochan Singh disbelieved by trial court; blood-stained sword recovery unreliable; site plan prepared later.

court_reasoning.text: FIR not unduly delayed: recorded 9:05 am, occurrence 7:30 am, distance 2.4 miles; SI Pritam Lal reached 10 am; no meaningful cross on PW13.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No undue delay in FIR or despatch of body.

court_reasoning.text: ASI Kashmiri Lal's account reliable: received info 7:40 am, forwarded 8:30 am, spot 8:40 am, inquest and despatch 9:45 am; denied tampering or late site plan.

Inquest alleged tampering (added '4' to injuries): even if true, does not detract from trustworthiness as not made to match five medical injuries; Hazara mentioned in FIR info due to land grudge, s.120B not suspicious.
Delayed s.157 report to magistrate (6 pm): improper but not tainting investigation where FIR prompt and no prejudice to accused.
Appellate court has full power to review evidence in acquittal appeal, not curtailed by trial court's reasonable view; must give reasons for disagreement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court followed principles in Sanwat Singh.

court_reasoning.text: High Court correctly appraised evidence; no error warranting Art.136 interference.

holdings.text: High Court justified in reversing acquittal and convicting Trilok Singh u/s 302 IPC and Pala Singh u/s 302/34 IPC.
Appellate court in acquittal appeal has full power to review evidence and reach own conclusion, expressing reasons.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sanwat Singh v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Summarises scope of appellate power in acquittal appeals: full review, principles from Sheo Swarup.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramabhupala Reddy v. State of AP
precedents_cited.relevance: Confirms Sanwat Singh principles on acquittal appeals.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bansidhar Mohanty v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Cited by petitioner on scope of acquittal appeals.
Principles guide appellate approach to acquittal appeals.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Charges against accused; convictions under 302 and 302/34.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Proceedings under 107; s.157 report delay; s.159 magistrate control.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by special leave against High Court's partial allowance of State appeal, upholding conviction of Trilok Singh under s.302 IPC and Pala Singh under s.302/34 IPC to life imprisonment; found no grounds to interfere under Art.136.

key_quotes.text: "An appellate Court has full powers to review the evidence upon which the order of acquittal is founded."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of power in acquittal appeals from Sanwat Singh.

key_quotes.text: "the different phraseology used... are not intended to curtail the undoubted power of an appellate court in an appeal against acquittal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies no restriction on appellate review.

key_quotes.text: High Court "considered the entire evidence in great detail... and came to the conclusion that the prosecution had fully proved the case against the two appellants."
key_quotes.speaker: court
